name: October 18, 2017
description:
It was October 18, 2017. Shohag, a melancholic soul, made a strong
determination that he will pursue Competitive Programming seriously, by heart,
because he found it fascinating. Fast forward to 4 years, he is happy that he
took this road. He is now creating a contest on Codeforces. He found an
astounding problem but has no idea how to solve this. Help him to solve the
final problem of the round. You are given three integers 
    n
, 
    k
 and

    x
. Find the number, modulo 
    998
     244
     353
, of integer sequences

    a_1, a_2, 
    …, a_n
 such that the following conditions are
satisfied: 
    0 
    ≤ a_i 
     2^k
 for each integer 
    i
 from 
    1

to 
    n
. There is no non-empty subsequence in 
    a
 such that the bitwise
XOR of the elements of the subsequence is 
    x
. A sequence 
    b
 is a
subsequence of a sequence 
    c
 if 
    b
 can be obtained from 
    c
 by
deletion of several (possibly, zero or all) elements. Input The first line
contains a single integer 
    t
 (
    1 
    ≤ t 
    ≤ 10^5
) — the number of
test cases. The first and only line of each test case contains three space-
separated integers 
    n
, 
    k
, and 
    x
 (
    1 
    ≤ n 
    ≤ 10^9
,

    0 
    ≤ k 
    ≤ 10^7
, 
    0 
    ≤ x 
     2^
    min(20,
    k)
). It is guaranteed that the sum of 
    k
 over all test cases does not
exceed 
    5 
    · 10^7
. Output For each test case, print a single integer
— the answer to the problem. Example Input 6 2 2 0 2 1 1 3 2 3 69 69 69 2017
10 18 5 7 0 Output 6 1 15 699496932 892852568 713939942 Note In the first test
case, the valid sequences are 
    [1, 2]
, 
    [1, 3]
, 
    [2, 1]
, 
    [2,
    3]
, 
    [3, 1]
 and 
    [3, 2]
. In the second test case, the only valid
sequence is 
    [0, 0]
.
